question.title: How to find the longer of two strings without if, switch or ternary?
question.body: How to implement a method that receives two strings and displays a message with the longer string and its length, without using if, switch or ternary operators?

answers.body:
You can make use of the fact that negative numbers will have a leading bit of 1. See two's complement.

// will print 'a' if the lengths are the same
static void printLongerString(String a, String b) {
  String[] arr = {a, b};

  int index = (a.length() - b.length()) >>> 31;
  String longer = arr[index];
  System.out.printf(
      "The longest string is '%s' with a length of %,d.%n", 
      longer, 
      longer.length());
}

If a.length() >= b.length() then the result of the subtraction will be a positive number or zero. In either case, the leading bit will be 0 and so >>> 31 will give you zero. Otherwise, the result of the subtraction will be negative, which means the leading bit will be 1 and >>> 31 will give you one.

Note this is just a fun exercise. You should not use this approach in real code. In real code, just do:

String longer = (a.length() >= b.length()) ? a : b;

Which is not only more readable but also more performant.

I am assuming that if the two strings have the same length, any of them will be OK as the longer.

I am finding the length by counting the code points in the string. In most cases this will count the characters, unlike using String.length(). More discussion of defining the length of a string below.

Use Collections.max() and a Comparator

As Anonymous said in a comment:

private static final Comparator<String> compareByLengthInCodePoints
        = Comparator.comparingInt(s -> s.codePointCount(0, s.length()));

public static void printLonger(String s1, String s2) {
    String longer = Collections.max(List.of(s1, s2), compareByLengthInCodePoints);
    System.out.println(longer + " length " + longer.codePointCount(0, longer.length()));
}

Try it out:

    String threeLetters = "abc";
    String twoSmileys = "\uD83D\uDE42\uD83D\uDE20";
    printLonger(threeLetters, twoSmileys);

Output:

abc length 3

As Anonymous also said, max() probably uses if in its implementations, though, so whether we have fulfilled the restrictions is up to interpretation. Then again, String.length() indirectly uses a ternary, COMPACT_STRINGS ? coder : UTF16, so it’s probably OK.

Or use a loop

As another solution we can use a while or for loop to simulate an if statement. This auxiliary method does that:

private static String getLongerString(String s1, String s2) {
    while (s1.codePointCount(0, s1.length()) > s2.codePointCount(0, s2.length())) {
        return s1;
    }
    return s2;
}

Just call it from the printLonger() method from before. My IDE warns me: 'while' statement does not loop. Which is exactly point.

Printing both strings if they have equal length

This method reports both strings in the case where they have the same length.

public static void printLonger(String s1, String s2) {
    Stream.of(s1, s2)
            .filter(s -> getCodePointCount(s) >= getCodePointCount(s1)
                    && getCodePointCount(s) >= getCodePointCount(s2))
            .forEach(s -> System.out.println(s + " length " + getCodePointCount(s)));;
}

private static int getCodePointCount(String s) {
    return s.codePointCount(0, s.length());
}

What is the length of a string?

The Java char type is virtually deprecated since is can no longer represent a general Unicode character. By extension also the String.length() method no longer gives a meaningful value since it gives the number of chars in the string.

A Java char is 16 bits, so there are 65 000 possible char values. Last time I checked, there were 292 000 different Unicode characters, and the number is still growing. So more than 4 times as many. Therefore some characters use two Java chars, for example smileys.

A character is therefore represented by a 32 bits code point, or by two consecutive chars in a string.

Counting code points still isn’t perfect. Some code points represent non-printing characters, for example change of reading direction or accents or other diacritical marks.

Yet other thinkable definitions of the length of a string would be the width in pixels when rendering the string using some specific font.

Link

Java - what are characters, code points and surrogates? What difference is there between them?

It seems to me that more important than the solution is the path that leads us to it, and I will try to reflect this.

First we divide the problem into smaller, more manageable problems (although it seems that no, it can be divided).

Let's start with the easy step: determining the variable that contains the longest string, although we will do so indirectly:

boolean isLongerStringA = stringA.length() > stringB.length();

We already have our first small step, let's go with the second one, how to return one of two variables without using... nothing (hahah), here I have stayed a good time thinking about it and I believe that the solution is unique:

int possibleAnswers[] = { stringA, stringB };

this in turn leads us directly to the last lines of our method:

System.out.println( "The longest string is: \"" + 
          possibleAnswers[ index ] + 
          "\" and has: " + 
          possibleAnswers[ index ].length() + 
          " letters"  );

  // It is also valid not to return anything
return possibleAnswers[ index ];

At this point, we just need to connect the first part with the second. To do so, we must answer the question: “How do I convert a Boolean to an integer?”

Getting an answer is like entering a room with many doors and going through them until you find the right one.
Some people will check two doors and leave, others will open the first door and find it, and then there are the “persistent” ones, who will open all the necessary doors until they find the solution.

I don't really know how I came to wonder what compareTo() returns in the Boolean class, but that led me to run the following code:

Boolean TRUE = true;
Boolean FALSE = false;
System.out.println( TRUE.compareTo( true ) );  // this printed  “0”
System.out.println( FALSE.compareTo( true ) ); // this printed “-1”

Yes, we've got it. We just need to make a small adjustment to get “1” and “0” instead of ‘0’ and “-1”, which will serve as the index.

we replace boolean isLongerStringA = stringA.length() > stringB.length(); by:

  // Note that we changed “stringA” to ‘stringB’ and “>” to “<” 
  // so that the index obtained is correct.
boolean isLongerStringB = stringA.length() < stringB.length();

so that we can use the compareTo() method of Boolean and finally:

int index = isLongerStringB.compareTo( true ) + 1;

Putting all the code together:

String eapp( String stringA, String stringB ) {
   Boolean isLongerStringB = stringA.length() < stringB.length();
   String possibleAnswers[] = { stringA, stringB };
   int index = isLongerStringB.compareTo( true ) + 1;
   System.out.println( "The longest string is: \"" + 
           possibleAnswers[ index ] + 
           "\" and has: " + 
           possibleAnswers[ index ].length() + 
           " letters"  );
   return possibleAnswers[ index ];
}

PS: Under “normal” circumstances, I would have waited a while before posting my own answer (so that others could find the solution themselves), but since it is very likely to end up being closed, I have decided to do it this way.

Edit:
As @Holger points out, the compare method invoked by compareTo in the Boolean class uses not one, but two ternary operators, so if we split hairs, my previous answer does not meet the requirements. Here is a second attempt:

void showLonger(  String a, String b  ) {
   String possibleAnswers[] = { a, b };
   int index = b.length() - a.length();
     // the “while” loops are responsible for keeping “index” 
     // within the expected values
   while( index < 0 ) index ++;
   while( index > 1 ) index--;
   System.out.println( possibleAnswers[ index ] + “ ” + possibleAnswers[ index ].length() );
}

This solution is not as efficient as the other answers, but much simpler. I would use Stream.max(Comparator):

public static Wrapper pickLonger(String first, String second) {
  return Stream.of(first, second)
          .map(Wrapper::new)
          .max(Comparator.comparingInt(Wrapper::length))
          .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Not happening"));
}

Wrapper class:

public class Wrapper {

  private final String string;
  private final int length;

  public Wrapper(String string) {
    this.string = string;
    this.length = string.length();
  }

  public String string() {
    return this.string;
  }

  public int length() {
    return this.length;
  }
}

question_comments.body: I think the spirit of the question is actually "without using any form of conditional branching". A while statement is a form of conditional branching.
( simple while example: String longer(String a, String b) { while (a.length() > b.length()) return a; return b;} {must be improved: consider null or same lengths} )
Use for example Collections.max(Collection, Comparator) to find the longer string (it probably uses if in its implementation, though).

79714313.body: "max() probably uses if in its implementations" cannot be a restriction, even String.length() uses a conditional operator (? :); or codePointCount() an if

79714266.body: Nice. Though I think the new Wrapper record is overkill. You were already returning the String, which already has a length() method. All the needed information was already there. Plus, now the "length" of the Wrapper can be different from the length of the String (that won't happen with the way you use it, but the API allows for that).

79714090.body: @MarcePuente The only thing that matters is the contract which says: “zero if this object represents the same boolean value as the argument; a positive value if this object represents true and the argument represents false; and a negative value if this object represents false and the argument represents true”. No guaranty to get 1 or -1.
( sure, the methods must return 0 if both values are equal, as documented )

@Marce - the source of compare or compareTo is an implementation detail; the developers of the JDK can change it to return something different than just -1, 0, and 1; they must only abide by the documentation (I've reasons not to post answers... Thanks, I know how to use the IDE, but usually I prefer, if not coding, to use the OpenJDK source on GitHub, seldom even the lib/src.zip that is part of not-so-old JDK distributions [also used by the IDE {if correctly configured} ] )

@user85421 This non-answer (I don't know why you don't publish it as such), along with Slaw's, seem to me to be the best (by far). Luckily, I said I would accept the first correct answer (I wouldn't want to have to choose between them). Regarding compareTo and compare, just use your favorite IDE, select one of them, right-click -> go to source (or similar) and you'll see how they are implemented.

if using while is allowed, there is a much simpler solution (as I already commented: String longer(String a, String b) { while (a.length() > b.length()) return a; return b;} - Code Golf candidate :-) )

btw, compareTo() or compare() can be used as argument of Integer.signum() which is documented to return only -1, 0 or +1 -- as I commented yesterday, String also uses if and the conditional operator, but String can hardly be avoided (so Slaw's answer is also "hiding a conditional somewhere") -- ( @Marce point 1 above is an implementation detail, not as documented [maybe it was in older versions] )

@Holger Point 1): compareTo depends on compare. If “A” is greater than “B,” it returns “1”; if they are equal, it returns “0”; and if ‘A’ is less than “B,” it returns “-1.” Point 2): It is true that it uses a ternary operator, but it remains to be seen whether the internal implementations of the language methods should respect the restrictions, as I explained in the original post. I copied the question, so I cannot answer that.

Letting aside that compareTo does not guaranty to return -1 but only makes guarantees about the sign of the result, it also just hides a conditional. In fact, even Boolean isLongerStringB = stringA.length() < stringB.length(); compiles to the equivalent of Boolean.valueOf(stringA.length() < stringB.length()? true: false) under the surface. Slaw’s answer is so far the only answer not hiding a conditional somewhere…
if you are allowed to use compareTo, why not compare the lengths directly? (Integer.compareTo() or even Intger.compare()) No need to use Boolean
I'm pretty sure the implementation of compareTo() uses if. And its return values need not be 1 or -1. If you're happy with your solution, don't take it as an objection, I'm happy too.
